name: 01 - Project Overview
content:
Telco Churn Prediction

Project Overview

Objective:

The main objective of this project is to predict whether a telecom customer is likely to churn (leave the service provider) based on their service usage behavior, account characteristics, and interactions with customer support. By identifying churn-prone customers in advance, the telecom operator can take proactive steps such as personalized retention offers, loyalty rewards, or improved service support to reduce churn and boost profitability.

Approach:

The project follows a structured classification workflow:

  1. Data Profiling & EDA – Understand distributions, churn vs. non-churn ratios, and usage patterns.
  2. Data Preparation – Clean the dataset (fix formatting issues in churn labels, compute derived features, encode categorical variables).
  3. Feature Engineering – Create new features such as total usage, domestic minutes, and account length groups.
  4. Model Training – Train a classification model using H2O Distributed Random Forest (DRF).
  5. Model Validation & Prediction – Evaluate model accuracy, precision, recall, and use the trained model for churn predictions.
  6. Business Insights – Visualize churn rates across usage categories and provide inputs for retention strategy.

Significance:

Customer churn is one of the most critical challenges in the telecom industry. By reducing churn:

  • Customer Lifetime Value (CLTV) is extended.
  • Revenue stability improves.
  • Competitive advantage is achieved by proactively retaining valuable customers.

Benefits:

  • Higher retention rates through targeted interventions.
  • Improved profitability by reducing customer acquisition costs.
  • Actionable insights into customer behavior and churn drivers.
  • Better customer experience through personalized retention efforts.

Expected Outcomes:

  • A robust predictive model to classify customers as churn or non-churn.
  • Identification of top factors influencing churn (e.g., high service calls, international plans, account length).
  • Analytical dashboards showing churn distribution across states, account lengths, and usage categories.
